app module

app.delete_not(notification_id)[source]
The delete_not function deletes a notification from the database.
Args:

notification_id (int): The id of the notification to be deleted.

Parameters:

notification_id – Delete the notification with a given id

Returns:

The redirect function, which returns a response object

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.delete_user(user_name)[source]
The delete_user function deletes a user from the database.
Args:

user_name (str): The name of the user to be deleted.

Parameters:

user_name – Pass the name of the user to be deleted

Returns:

A redirect to the users page

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.edit_user(user_name)[source]

The edit_user function allows you to edit a user’s information.

Parameters:

user_name – Identify which user to edit

Returns:

‘not implemented’

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.edition(notification_id)[source]

The edition function is responsible for editing the notification. It takes one argument, which is the id of a notification to be edited. The function first checks if user is logged in and if not, redirects him to login page. If he’s logged in it renders edition template with data from database (notification). When user submits form with new data, this function updates database.

Parameters:

notification_id – Identify the notification that is being edited

Returns:

The edition

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.form()[source]

The form function is responsible for handling the form.html template, which allows users to submit a notification about a problem in their room. The function checks if the user is logged in and if not, redirects them to the login page with an appropriate flash message. If they are logged in, it renders the form template and waits for POST requests from it.

Returns:

A redirect to the form_content function

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.form_content()[source]

The form_content function is used to render the form_content.html template, which contains a form that allows users to submit complaints about their hotel rooms. The function takes in four arguments: priorytet, skarga, numer_pokoju and nazwisko_zlgaszajacego. These are all strings that will be passed into the HTML template as variables.

Returns:

A rendered template

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.index()[source]

The index function is the default function that gets called when a user visits the root of the website. It renders the index.html template, which contains all of our HTML code for displaying content on this page.

Returns:

A rendered template

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.init_app()[source]

The init_app function is used to initialize the application. It checks if there are any active users in the database, and if not, it creates a new user with admin privileges.

Returns:

A redirect to the index page

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.login()[source]
The login function is used to log in a user.

It takes no arguments and returns nothing.

Returns:

The rendered template login

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.logout()[source]
The logout function is used to logout the user from the session.

It checks if there is a ‘user’ in session, and if so it pops it out of the session and flashes a message saying that you have been logged out.

Returns:

A redirect to the login page

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.new_user()[source]

The new_user function is responsible for creating a new user. It first checks if the user is logged in as an admin, and if not, redirects them to the login page. If they are logged in as an admin, it then checks whether or not there was a POST request made to this function. If so, it creates a new User object using the UserFactory class and inserts that into our database.

Returns:

A redirect to the users function

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.notifications()[source]

The notifications function is responsible for displaying all notifications in the database. It also checks if the user is logged in and if he has admin rights. If not, it displays only his own notifications.

Returns:

The notifications

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.user_status_change(action, user_name)[source]

The user_status_change function is called when the user clicks on a button to change the status of another user. The function takes two arguments: action and user_name. The action argument can be either ‘active’ or ‘admin’. If it’s active, then we toggle whether that particular user is active or not by adding 1 to their current value mod 2 (which will flip between 0 and 1). If it’s admin, then we do the same thing but for their admin status instead.

Parameters:

  • action – Determine if the user is being made active or admin

  • user_name – Identify the user that is to be changed

Returns:

A redirect to the users page

Doc-author:

Trelent

app.users()[source]

The users function is used to display a list of all users in the database. It also checks if the user is logged in as an admin, and if not, redirects them to login page.

Returns:

A rendered template

Doc-author:

Trelent
